President Alexander Lukashenko, who has held power since 1994, has announced his intention to seek reelection (1). Overview.Summary: In 2024, Belarusian President Alexander Lukashenko announced his intention to seek re-election, extending his grip on the country to 36 years (1,2). However, Belarus refused to invite OSCE observers to monitor the parliamentary election (3). The election reinforced Lukashenko's authoritarian rule, with only loyal candidates allowed to compete and opposition calling for a boycott (4,6). The election also involved voting for local councils and the House of Representatives (5). The US called the election a "sham" (9) and the constitutional amendments approved in 2022 introduced changes including extending the term of parliamentary deputies and limiting the presidency to two terms (10).

Overview.Summary: The 2024 Belarusian parliamentary election (20) is expected to extend President Alexander Lukashenko's grip on the country to 36 years (7). Lukashenko announced his intention to seek re-election (1,2,7) and has signed a law granting him lifelong immunity from criminal prosecution (3). The opposition is endorsing an AI candidate (8) and has criticized the election as not being "free and fair" (9). International observers will be accredited to monitor the election (17) and the nomination of candidates will begin on March 12 (20).

Timeline.Text: Belarusian President Alexander Lukashenko announces he will seek re-election next year.
Belarusian President Alexander Lukashenko signs a law granting him lifelong immunity from criminal prosecution.
The House of Commons Library releases a timetable for the 2024 general election in Belarus, with polling day set for January 28.
The Belarusian presidential and legislative elections are held.
